Mridul, where does the testing data (i.e. what you will test it on after =
training is over) come from?  Is it from a different graph or the same grap=
h?  The reason I ask is that it probably matters whether the nodes will be =
the same nodes (i.e. because they are from the same graph) or nodes from an=
 entirely different graph.

In general, it does sound like you could create=
 an array of 9000 inputs and highlight the ones that you are asking about. =
 The main question for HyperNEAT is whether those 9000 inputs can be situat=
ed in a meaningful geometry?  For example, is it naturally 300x300?  Or may=
be something else?  If there is a geometry to them, and if there are regula=
rities in their connectivity, then in principle HyperNEAT might be a good c=
hoice for learning that pattern.

Also, note that with 9000 inputs, there w=
ill generally be a computational cost to activating the network.

ken

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p_mridul" <p_mridul@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I am=
 working on a bioinformatics problem, but it's easier to talk about it in g=
raph theory terms....
> 
> I have a graph with a large number of nodes (~90=
00), and about 3000 edges between the nodes... I am planning to feed this a=
s training data, and then see if the resulting NN will predict the probabil=
ity of an edge given any 2 nodes.
> 
> I have questions of how to encode th=
e inputs... do I create an input array of 9000 inputs and pass in the coupl=
e of 1's corresponding to the nodes, or do I choose 2 inputs & pass in the =
node numbers?
> 
> Thanks,
> Mridul.
>
